Plots Global Model Explanations (Variable Importance)
  • Reference

    • Survival on the RMS Titanic

Plots Global Model Explanations (Variable Importance)

Function plot.variable_dropout_explainer plots dropouts for variables used in the model. It uses output from variable_dropout function that corresponds to permutation based measure of variable importance. Variables are sorted in the same order in all panels. The order depends on the average drop out loss. In different panels variable contributions may not look like sorted if variable importance is different in different in different mdoels.

# S3 method for variable_importance_explainer
plot(x, ..., max_vars = 10,
  bar_width = 10, show_baseline = FALSE)

Arguments

x

a variable dropout exlainer produced with the 'variable_dropout' function
...

other explainers that shall be plotted together
max_vars

maximum number of variables that shall be presented for for each model
bar_width

width of bars. By default 10
show_baseline

logical. Should the baseline be included?

Value

a ggplot2 object

Examples


 
library("breakDown")
library("randomForest")
HR_rf_model <- randomForest(left~., data = breakDown::HR_data, ntree = 100)
#> Warning: The response has five or fewer unique values.  Are you sure you want to do regression?
explainer_rf  <- explain(HR_rf_model, data = HR_data, y = HR_data$left)
vd_rf <- variable_importance(explainer_rf, type = "raw")
vd_rf
#>                 variable dropout_loss        label
#> 1           _full_model_     2.487968 randomForest
#> 2                   left     2.487968 randomForest
#> 3  promotion_last_5years     2.557563 randomForest
#> 4          Work_accident     3.405990 randomForest
#> 5                 salary     4.879371 randomForest
#> 6                  sales     5.230747 randomForest
#> 7   average_montly_hours    77.837101 randomForest
#> 8     time_spend_company    83.300030 randomForest
#> 9        last_evaluation   105.246517 randomForest
#> 10        number_project   105.471699 randomForest
#> 11    satisfaction_level   165.939976 randomForest
#> 12            _baseline_   334.616998 randomForest
plot(vd_rf)

HR_glm_model <- glm(left~., data = breakDown::HR_data, family = "binomial")
explainer_glm <- explain(HR_glm_model, data = HR_data, y = HR_data$left)
logit <- function(x) exp(x)/(1+exp(x))
vd_glm <- variable_importance(explainer_glm, type = "raw",
                        loss_function = function(observed, predicted)
                                   sum((observed - logit(predicted))^2))
vd_glm
#>                 variable dropout_loss label
#> 1           _full_model_     265.8276    lm
#> 2                   left     265.8276    lm
#> 3        last_evaluation     265.8510    lm
#> 4  promotion_last_5years     265.9550    lm
#> 5   average_montly_hours     266.0752    lm
#> 6                  sales     266.0848    lm
#> 7         number_project     267.0627    lm
#> 8          Work_accident     267.6243    lm
#> 9     time_spend_company     267.6448    lm
#> 10                salary     268.3802    lm
#> 11    satisfaction_level     280.4374    lm
#> 12            _baseline_     286.1795    lm
plot(vd_glm)

library("xgboost")
model_martix_train <- model.matrix(left~.-1, breakDown::HR_data)
data_train <- xgb.DMatrix(model_martix_train, label = breakDown::HR_data$left)
param <- list(max_depth = 2, eta = 1, silent = 1, nthread = 2,
              objective = "binary:logistic", eval_metric = "auc")
HR_xgb_model <- xgb.train(param, data_train, nrounds = 50)
explainer_xgb <- explain(HR_xgb_model, data = model_martix_train,
                                    y = HR_data$left, label = "xgboost")
vd_xgb <- variable_importance(explainer_xgb, type = "raw")
vd_xgb
#>                 variable dropout_loss   label
#> 1           _full_model_     17.07852 xgboost
#> 2             salessales     16.87784 xgboost
#> 3  promotion_last_5years     16.96999 xgboost
#> 4           salarymedium     17.03465 xgboost
#> 5        salesaccounting     17.07852 xgboost
#> 6                salesIT     17.07852 xgboost
#> 7        salesmanagement     17.07852 xgboost
#> 8         salesmarketing     17.07852 xgboost
#> 9       salesproduct_mng     17.14017 xgboost
#> 10          salessupport     17.16225 xgboost
#> 11               saleshr     17.21277 xgboost
#> 12            salesRandD     17.39273 xgboost
#> 13        salestechnical     17.63472 xgboost
#> 14         Work_accident     17.91355 xgboost
#> 15             salarylow     19.55793 xgboost
#> 16  average_montly_hours     37.81782 xgboost
#> 17       last_evaluation     44.25711 xgboost
#> 18        number_project     47.21579 xgboost
#> 19    time_spend_company     60.95065 xgboost
#> 20    satisfaction_level    160.27481 xgboost
#> 21            _baseline_    355.90120 xgboost
plot(vd_xgb)

plot(vd_rf, vd_glm, vd_xgb)

# NOTE:
# if you like to have all importances hooked to 0, you can do this as well
vd_rf <- variable_importance(explainer_rf, type = "difference")
vd_glm <- variable_importance(explainer_glm, type = "difference",
                        loss_function = function(observed, predicted)
                                   sum((observed - logit(predicted))^2))
vd_xgb <- variable_importance(explainer_xgb, type = "difference")
plot(vd_rf, vd_glm, vd_xgb)
